fields.descriptive_line: Wings for a butterfly costume, ca. 1930s-1940s.
fields.physical_description:
[Theatre costume] Double sided triangle with scalloped base of bright rose artificial silk blending into brown rose at the lower edge.  Towards the lower edge are two irregular crescents in palest lemon yellow edged with large purple sequins and decorated with densely packed circles of large black sequins and lines of blue sequins.  Down the wings, splaying out from the upper corner, are 'veins' of lines of gold sequins, interspersed on the upper half with lines of pink shield-shaped sequins, and on the lower with lines of gold seqins.  The second side of the wing is a mirror image of the first; the two pieces are linked around the edge with a band of gold metal braid around a white cord.   At the upper edge are loops of elastic to fit around the arm.

fields.materials_techniques:
[Theatre costume] Artificial silk, sequins, gold metal braid around cotton cord, elastic armbands

fields.public_access_description:
These butterfly wings were part of a costume worn in shows at the Theatre Royal, Leeds, in the 1930s and 1940s, maybe in the flying ballets, which were a feature of several productions.  The 'fliers' were attached to wires and swung out over the auditorium, where they dropped flowers onto the audience.   
Butterflies were extremely popular in the first decades of the 20th century; as they were aerial creatures with an amazing variety of colour, they were an obvious subject for dancers or for scenes in the spectacular pantomimes that were produced in every major city and town in England.  The concept was simple - a leotard was decorated to simulate a segmented insect body, the fitted helmet headdress was topped with 'antennae' and the brightly coloured and sequinned wings were then attached at the centre back and to the wrists or fingers.  When these costumes came to the Museum, it was impossible to accurately match 'bodies' and 'wings', so the wings were catalogued separately.  In fact, in the hurly-burly that is a theatre wardrobe, performers were probably dressed in any combination of  leotard and wings that came to hand.   
Whereas a costume worn by a star performer or a particularly stunning design might be preserved, theatre costumes of this style and period, worn by a succession of unknown performers, are comparatively rare.  They might go into the theatre stock wardrobe and worn until they fell to pieces, or just thrown out to make room because noone thought they were of any interest. A few, like this costume, were saved by people who worked in the theatre or their friends.
fields.credit: Given by Mrs M E Craggs
fields.history_note:
The wings were part of a butterfly costume, worn in shows at the Theatre Royal, Leeds, in the 1930s and 1940s.  They would have been worn with 'bodies' and headdresses like S.7-2004, S.8-2004 and S.9-2004, although it has not been possible to do an exact match between the wings and the 'bodies' in this gift. 
A feature of the shows were the flying ballets which featured in various productions; girls would bring violet posies onto the stage and the 'flyers' would be flown out from the stage round over the auditorium, drop the posies to the audience, and back to the stage.
